abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and both the Bank, and the
            Borrower performances were satisfactory. Several lessons are
            drawn from the project, namely, that, technical assistance
            lending (TAL) instruments, have limitations in addressing
            structural issues, for however effective the operation may
            be, an optimum performance on decisive political actions, or
            complex decisions, should not be expected. This was probably
            the case with the insurance, and securities market reform,
            and, experience suggests that this operation could have been
            more successful, had it supported a policy oriented Bank
            operation. The tendency to overestimate the capacity to
            absorb technical assistance, is proven by the fact that even
            under sound administrative structures, procurement becomes
            limited, subject to unforeseen frictions, and, furthermore,
            TALs are administratively demanding, and management
            intensive operations. Hence, assumption of the perfect
            project design, may be counterproductive, since a less
            ambitious design could better outline TAL objectives, with
            detailed work plans for the first implementation year, to be
            followed by agreements, for the annual review process to
            examine. While the operation benefited from the inclusion of
            an experienced Project Unit, the Bank should avoid financing
            its cost, for, project accountability better improves when
            the unit is government funded.
